case_name: Travancore-Cochin v. The Cochin Coal Company Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1958 is an appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th September, 1956, of the High Court of Travancore-Cochin in Original Petition No. 191 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1958. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th September, 1956, of the former Travancore-Cochin in Original Petition No. 191 of 1955.

facts.text: The respondent is The Cochin Coal Company Ltd., dealers in coal.

anchor.surface_text: The Cochin Coal Company Ltd. which will be referred to as the respondent-Company are, as their name indicates, dealers in coal.

facts.text: The commodity is bunker coal.

anchor.surface_text: The commodity, the sales of which have given rise to the dispute in this appeal is what is known as Bunker coal.

facts.text: The company has offices at Fort Cochin which was formerly within the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The company have their offices at a place called Fort Cochin which was formerly within the State of Madras.

facts.text: They import and keep stocks of bunker coal at Candle Island which was within the State of Madras at relevant date.

anchor.surface_text: They import and keep stocks of bunker coal stacked at a place called Candle Island which at the date relevant to these proceedings was also within the State of Madras.

facts.text: Supply of bunker coal from depots in Candle Island to steamers arriving in or calling at the port of Cochin in Travancore-Cochin for outward voyage.

anchor.surface_text: Part of the activities of the respondent-company consist in the supply of bunker coal from their depots in Candle Island to steamers arriving in or calling at, the port of Cochin  in the State of Travancore-Cochin  for the outward voyage of the steamers from the said port.

facts.text: Steamer agents enter into contracts with respondent company for trimming coal into bunker of steamer before arrival.

anchor.surface_text: The usual procedure by which bunker coal was thus supplied by the respondent company was briefly this Before the arrival of the steamers, the steamer agents would enter into contracts with the respondent company for trimming coal into the bunker of the steamer.

facts.text: Upon steamer arrival, agents inform company, secure papers from customs and port authorities, take to company's office in Fort Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as a steamer arrived in Cochin port, the steamer- agents would inform the respondent-company and these agents after securing the necessary papers from the customs and the port authorities for the loading of the coal into the steamer, would take these papers to the respondent-company's office in Fort Cochin for enabling the latter to perform their part of the contract.

facts.text: Company sends goods to steamer through transport contractor; delivery orders issued for release from Candle Island.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-company would thereupon send the goods ordered to the steamer through their transport contractor. Delivery orders would be issued to the transport contractor on the strength of which goods would be released from their stock in Candle Island.

facts.text: Coal taken to steamer berthed in port in Travancore-Cochin State waters.

anchor.surface_text: Coal would then be taken to the steamer berthed in the port in Travancore-Cochin State waters.

facts.text: Chief Engineer inspects coal; if satisfactory, trimmed into bunkers.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Engineer of the steamer would inspect the coal and when the same was to his satisfaction as regards quality, the coal would be per- mitted to be trimmed into the bunkers of the ships.

facts.text: Price paid to company on bills drawn on steamer-agent.

anchor.surface_text: The price of the coal would thereafter be paid to the respondent-company on bills drawn on the steamer-agent.

facts.text: Sales-tax claimed on sales of bunker coal by Travancore-Cochin State.

anchor.surface_text: The above being the nature of the transactions conducted by the respondent-company, sales-tax was claimed on the sales of bunker coal by the Travancore-Cochin State.

facts.text: Assessment years 1951-52 and 1952-53; assessment completed on February 2, 1954 by Sales Tax Officer, Circle, Mattancherry.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment years with which this appeal is concerned are 1951-52 and 1952-53, and the assessment therefore was completed on February 2, 1954, by the sales-tax officer, Circle, Mattancherry.

facts.text: Respondent contended no sales-tax leviable as sale in course of export or inter-State trade, exempt under Art. 286(1)(b) or (2).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-company's contention that no sales-tax could be levied on the value of the bunker coal supplied, since the sale was either in the course of export , or in the course of inter-State trade and therefore exempted from taxation by the State under sub-cl.  1  b  or  2  of Art. 286

facts.text: Assessing officer rejected contention, held sales within Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a), delivery in State for consumption in State.

anchor.surface_text: was rejected by the assessing officer for the reason that the sales in question fell within the Explanation to Art. 286  1  a  and were therefore inside the State of Travancore-Cochin, since the delivery in pursuance of the sale took place within the State and the goods were delivered for the purpose of consumption within the State

facts.text: Company urged same sales assessed to tax in Madras State; rejected as irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: The point urged by the company, that the same sales had been assessed to tax in Madras State as sales actually taking place there, was also rejected as irrelevant

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed, holding sales in course of export under Art. 286(1)(b) or exempted by notification dated February 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-company thereafter filed an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who allowed the appeal of the company holding that the sales were in the course of export within Art. 286 1  b , and that even if they were not such but were ,inside sales falling within the Explanation to Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution, still a notification by the State Government dated February 5, 1954, exempting such sales from tax,

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of sales-tax took up suo motu in revision, set aside appellate order, restored STO order.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Deputy Commissioner of sales-tax who was the Revisional authority took up the matter suo motu, called upon the assessee to show cause why the appellate order should not be set aside and the entire turnover assessed to sales-tax as the sales had taken place inside the State only. After hearing the assessee-company the order of the appellate Assistant Commissioner was set aside and that of the Sales Tax Officer restored.

facts.text: High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 set aside revision order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-company then moved the High Court of Travancore-Cochin under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution to set aside the order in revision and the learned Judges of the High Court ordered accordingly.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1) to State.

anchor.surface_text: They, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution to enable the State Government to file an appeal to this Court

facts.text: Notification dated February 5, 1954 published in Gazette February 16, 1954 exempting certain inter-State sales before April 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In the Travancore-Cochin Gazette dated February 16, 1954, the following notification dated February 5, 1954, appeared According to the interpretation given by the Supreme Court to Art. 286 1  of the Constitution in their judgment in the State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd.

facts.text: The transaction of sale was in the course of inter-State trade.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the transaction of sale in the present case was in the course of inter-State trade and would be covered by the ban on taxation imposed by Art. 286 2 .

facts.text: Delivery of coal effected in Travancore-Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: The delivery was admittedly effected in the State of Travancore-Cochin as a direct result of that sale and was trimmed into the steam-ships in the Cochin waters.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by AYYANGAR J. on October 31, 1960.

holdings.text: The transaction of sale in the present case was in the course of inter-State trade and would be covered by the ban on taxation imposed by Art. 286(2).

anchor.surface_text: There is nodoubt that the transaction of sale in the present case was in the companrse of inter-State trade and would be companyered by the ban on taxation imposed by Art. 286 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods imported to Madras, stocked there, moved to Travancore-Cochin port under sale contract for delivery there.

holdings.text: The view of the High Court that s.26 of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act does not levy tax on sales in the course of inter-State trade is incorrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validation Act saves levy on inter-State sales that state law purported to tax.

holdings.text: The sale was not in the course of export within Art. 286(1)(b) as bunker coal lacks foreign destination terminus.

anchor.surface_text: The first was that as the companl trimmed into the steam-ships were. meant to be carried outside the territory of India, the sale was in the companrse of export within Art. 286  1  b  of the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Burmah Shell case: export requires two termini, mere movement out of India insufficient without import into foreign territory.

holdings.text: The sale falls within the Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) as delivery effected in Travancore-Cochin for purpose of consumption therein.

anchor.surface_text: the other point urged by learned Counsel was that, in any event, the sale fell within the Explanation to Art. 286 1 a  inasmuch as the delivery of the companl was effected

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delivery to ultimate consumer (ship) for use/consumption in state, even if later moved out; consumption by use, not requiring destruction or fixed location.

holdings.text: The notification dated February 5, 1954 exempts these sales from tax under s.6(1) of the Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: But the submission of learned Counsel was that the State Government had power to exempt sales of any particular designated type from tax liability under s. 6 of the Sales-Tax Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification validly issued under s.6(1), covers inter-State sales treated as inside sales for assessment years 1951-52, 1952-53 per United Motors interpretation.

precedents.cited_proposition: in the context and setting in which the expression export out of the territory of India occurs in Part XIII of the Constitution, it was not sufficient that goods were merely moved out of the territory of India but that it was further necessary that the goods should be intended to be transported to a destination beyond India [...] aviation spirit sold to an aircraft for enabling it to fly out of the country was not exported out of the country
precedents.cited_holding: a mere movement of the goods out of the country following a sale would not render the sale one in the course of export within Art. 286 1 b of the Constitution
